title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.8.31 | 27-02-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: Though fear personified is afraid of you, this sight is bewildering to me.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam (SB 1.8.31) and explains the meaning of Queen Kunti's prayer, focusing on the bewildering nature of Krishna's pastimes.

segments.key_quote: Here is a specific example of the Lord's being the supreme at the same time a plaything in the presence of his pure devotee.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's purport, emphasizing Krishna's eternal supremacy and how He becomes a plaything in the presence of His pure devotee, Mother Yashoda.

segments.key_quote: And while discharging such devotional service to the Supreme Lord, the pure devotee forgets that the Krishna is actually the Supreme Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the nature of pure devotion, highlighting how pure devotees serve Krishna out of unalloyed love and often forget His supreme position.

segments.key_quote: he relishes more if his devotees render him spontaneous loving service, than when the devotees render him devotional service out of reverence for him as the greatest.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the devotion in Vaikuntha, characterized by reverence, with the spontaneous love in Goloka Vrindavan, which Krishna relishes more.

segments.key_quote: Krishna accepts the chastisement by his devotees like his parents, more lovingly than he accepts the prayers of the Vedas, which glorify him in so many ways as the greatest.
segments.summary: The speaker provides examples of Krishna's friends and parents in Vrindavan and emphasizes that Krishna values the loving chastisement of his devotees more than the prayers of the Vedas.

segments.key_quote: Krishna, when he came to this material world, he wanted to show to the people of this world, what are the kind of pastimes that go on between himself and his pure devotees in Goloka Vrindavana.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Krishna descended to show the pastimes of Goloka Vrindavan, giving the example of Krishna stealing butter and being scolded by Yashoda.

segments.key_quote: When tears were rolling down Krishna's eyes, they were washing the mascara, which Yashoda used to decorate his eyes with.
segments.summary: The speaker describes Yashoda's attempt to punish Krishna, Krishna's feigned fear and tears, and the contrast between Krishna's fear of Yashoda and the fear that He inspires in the universe.

segments.key_quote: It is the loving exchange that Krishna relishes.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts Kunti's awareness of Krishna's supreme position with Yashoda's forgetfulness, emphasizing that Krishna relishes the loving exchange with his devotees.

segments.key_quote: They all know Krishna is the Supreme Personality of God.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the exalted position of Krishna's devotees and clarifies that their forgetfulness of Krishna's supreme position is not due to ignorance, illustrating with the mud-eating pastime.

segments.key_quote: And this is the eternal position of Krishna in the spiritual world. In his loving exchanges with his devotees.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how Krishna uses Yogamaya to conceal his greatness from Yashoda and concludes by reiterating the eternal nature of Krishna's loving exchanges with his devotees in the spiritual world.
